timeline.message:
Cleanup and address code review comments.

Summary of changes:
1) Below new test cases added:
   - Test for code path when optional values are mostly null
   - Test for case when containers are not reused for every batch
   - Test for case to verify arrow's validity vector is set correctly when setArrowValidityVector = true
2) Reuse container logic is now similar to row based read path
3) We now always set the nullability holder. Arrow validity vector is set only for purpose of supplying complete arrow vectors when requested to do so.
Run gradle build instead of check since build runs assembly + check
Run gradle build instead of check since build runs assembly + check

timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Yes

timeline.bodyText: Why convert directly from Arrow to Spark? Shouldn't this make guarantees about Arrow storage fields that are used for a given Iceberg type instead?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: bSize is batch size? If so, batchSize is more clear.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText:
Should there be more checking that numRows is valid? It should be the same for all vectors, right?
What happens when all of the result vectors are null? Looks like this will set the batch length to 0, but I think we want to set it to something valid.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: You might want to move this into a factory method for IcebergArrowColumnVector instead of embedding it here. This logic looks more related to how column vectors work than to the batch. Here, you could just call IcebergArrowColumnVector.forHolder(holder) and that would return either the null vector or a real one.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Nit: no need for this empty line.
timeline.author: rdblue
rdblue

timeline.bodyText: The data type methods could be static instead. Could you break this class into SparkArrowTypeUtil and something like ArrowAllocation?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: I thought we supported maps?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Not currently, no.
replies.author: samarthjain

timeline.bodyText: Doesn't Spark check nullability and only call these methods if isNullAt is false? I thought that was why it isn't necessary to check this in the primitive methods, like getLong.
timeline.author: rdblue
rdblue

timeline.bodyText: It would be nice to have an error message with the type that was accessed.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Can we move these to a separate file? The convention used elsewhere is to put ArrowVectorAccessor in a file and the implementations in a ArrowVectorAccessors class with a private constructor.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Isn't the use of final in Arrow causing us trouble? Why use final here? Does it have a performance benefit?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: ArrowVectorAccessor doesn't define getStruct. Do you mean getChild?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: I think these should process the dictionary first to transform each value to a Decimal and then use that table instead of the dictionary at read time.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Nit: the indentation here was correct before.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Nit: no need to remove this line.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText:
Options that enable/disable should use "enabled". That avoids users needing to think about whether options enable or disable - true always enables and false always disables.
I recommend using iceberg.read.parquet-vectorization.enabled.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: How about iceberg.read.parquet-vectorization.batch-size?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Javadoc: Instead of [...], did you mean to use either {@link ...} to link to the class, or {@code ...} to use fixed-width font?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Can we move this refactor into a separate PR?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: I am going to leave these changes in this PR and start a new PR for the refactor. Once the refactor PR is approved, I will merge those changes into this PR.

replies.bodyText: Opened #853
replies.author: samarthjain

timeline.bodyText: It would be nice to make the names shorter. What about BaseTaskReader, BatchTaskReader, and RowTaskReader?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Nit: Can you remove =>?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Why would enableBatchRead be null? Why not use a boolean instead?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: enableBatchRead is of type Boolean. It is lazily initialized in enableBatchRead().
replies.author: samarthjain

replies.bodyText: Accessing the enableBatchRead that is lazily computed creates an order dependency between this and enableBatchRead(). I'd rather simplify this and use the method call directly.
replies.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Style: control flow statements should be followed by empty lines.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Style: We typically indent method args from the same location. That would be either like it was before, or moving all of the method args to use the 4-space continuation indent.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Nit: unnecessary newline.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Nit: extra newline.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Why doesn't this support preferred locations?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: This should be enableBatchRead().
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Looks like the only differences between the batch and row tasks is the locality and batch size. Locality should probably be supported by both. If that's done, then do we need 3 classes? What about using one and using batchSize=1 for row-based tasks? Then we'd be able to have just one class for both cases.
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: I think 3 classes are still needed since we create different InputPartitionReader for each version.
replies.author: samarthjain

replies.bodyText: You're right. That was changed in a later version of the API. What about using anonymous classes and an abstract BaseReadTask? That might be clean, but up to you.
replies.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Could this implement VectorHolder and get passed into the read method, rather than allocating a VectorHolder and copying its contents?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Not sure I follow, @rdblue.
replies.author: samarthjain

timeline.bodyText: Is this necessary if we always eagerly decode ints?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText:
Have we tested using IntVector instead of DateDayVector?
It would simplify the decoding logic to always use an IntVector, and I'm not sure what the benefit of using a DateDayVector is. Isn't the underlying buffer identical?
Same logic applies for TimeStampMicroTZVector and LongVector.
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Filed #834 to follow up on this.
replies.author: samarthjain

timeline.bodyText: Does NullableVarCharHolder make a copy?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText:
No, it uses the underlying buffer and sets the start and end positions to get the variable width data out of it.
https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/maint-0.14.x/java/vector/src/main/java/org/apache/arrow/vector/VarCharVector.java#L134
replies.author: samarthjain

timeline.bodyText: This looks concerning to me. This variant of UTF8String uses Java's Unsafe to work with bytes underneath an object. By setting this to null, this is using an absolute address, which I assume should be off-heap. Does our allocator use off-heap memory?
timeline.author: rdblue

Preconditions accept a format string and arguments to avoid string creation every time the method is called, which is what happens when you use concatenation like this. Can you update the check like this?
Preconditions.checkArgument(numRowsToRead > 0, "Invalid number of rows to read: %s", numRowsToRead);

I don't see BYTE and SHORT type in https://github.com/apache/incubator-iceberg/blob/master/api/src/main/java/org/apache/iceberg/types/Type.java
So I would assume so?
replies.author: samarthjain

replies.bodyText: Looks good to me.
replies.author: rdblue

timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Did I already ask why this is necessary?
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText:
This was copied over from Spark's ArrowColumnVector
https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/master/sql/catalyst/src/main/java/org/apache/spark/sql/vectorized/ArrowColumnVector.java#L108
The difference from Spark's implementation is that our isNullAt(rowId) goes to the NullabilityHolder where as Spark's uses vector.isNull(rowId);
For spark, we don't set the validity bits in the validity vector since we track that piece of information in NullabilityHolder.
replies.author: samarthjain

replies.bodyText: But doesn't Spark already check nullability before calling this method?
replies.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: No, spark doesn't. See - https://github.com/apache/spark/blob/branch-2.4/sql/core/src/main/java/org/apache/spark/sql/execution/vectorized/MutableColumnarRow.java#L135
replies.author: samarthjain
samarthjain

timeline.bodyText: Instead of childColumns() and then accessing an ordinal, why not change the method to accessor.childColumn(int pos)?
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: Let's remove this Precondition. An invalid ordinal will cause an automatic exception and there is no need to check twice.
timeline.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText:
We need to make sure the extra filter columns are added in the reader and returned to Spark (so Spark expects the projection). This can't return a different set of columns than expected because columns are accessed by ordinal.
Another option is to do the ColumnarBatch projection here (remove filter columns that have been used), but I would prefer to just return everything to Spark. That simplifies both row and batch read paths.
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: Upon looking closer, I think BaseDataReader and RowDataReader classes can be merged. The only difference between BatchDataReader and RowDataReader is how in the former case we don't currently handle identity partition columns. I will spin up a PR for getting that refactoring into master. Once that is in, the only method that we would need to override in BatchDataReader would be Iterator<ColumnarBatch> open(FileScanTask task, Schema readSchema)
replies.author: samarthjain

replies.bodyText: Turns out, I think it makes sense to not merge the two classes. However, a lot of the functionality can be moved to the BaseDataReader class with override for specialized handling of identity partition columns. PR for refactoring - #1000
replies.author: samarthjain

replies.bodyText: I opened #1004 to remove the special handling for extra filter columns. When that's merged, we won't need to handle it. That's what I was talking about with this comment. Can you see how that changes the need for #1000?
replies.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText:
So the idea behind the need for #1000 was to provide only those methods that need to be customized for the two readers. In turn, it would have taken care of the special handling for extra filter columns and other common functionality that would have been introduced in the future.
I think #1000 is still relevant. It will need to change though if your PR goes in first :)
replies.author: samarthjain

timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText:
While it makes it cleaner, it is less efficient than exiting early. For ex-
boolean allParquetFileScanTasks =
          tasks().stream()
              .allMatch(combinedScanTask -> !combinedScanTask.isDataTask() && combinedScanTask.files()
                  .stream()
                  .allMatch(fileScanTask -> fileScanTask.file().format().equals(
                      FileFormat.PARQUET)));

The above is probably a somewhat expensive operation since it is iterating through all the files. We don't want to execute this is batch read has been disabled by config.
replies.author: samarthjain

replies.bodyText: Why does this need to be efficient? I think that the primary concern should be readability here because this is executed at planning time and the result is cached.
replies.author: rdblue

timeline.bodyText: This has a warning that it may produce NullPointerException. It would be better to initialize childColumns to new ArrowColumnVector[0] so that this throws an IndexOutOfBoundsException instead. That would also avoid needing to check if it is null in close.

timeline.bodyText:
Options passed into the read here should be short options because they come from the DataFrameReader interface:
spark.read.format("iceberg").config("snapshot-id", snapId).load("db.table");
The long option names like the ones you have here are what we use for table properties, which are tracked in TableProperties and documented. These options should default to the table property value, but a DataFrameReader option should override.
For short names, how about vectorization-enabled and batch-size? We should also add constants in TableProperties for the properties you have here. Let's turn off vectorization by default.
Also, we can drop "iceberg" from the start of the properties.
timeline.author: rdblue

replies.bodyText: I included this change in the PR against your branch.
replies.author: rdblue

timeline.message: iceberg-spark changes for vectorized reads
Minor cleanup
Address code review comments
Remove benchmarks from the code review
Merge reader changes from master. Rebase branch to master
Code review comments
Code review comments
Some changes from the review.
Enable projection tests for vectorized Parquet.
Revert changes to AvroDataTest.
Run TestParquetScan tests with vectorization enabled.

Summary of changes:
1) Below new test cases added:
   - Test for code path when optional values are mostly null
   - Test for case when containers are not reused for every batch
   - Test for case to verify arrow's validity vector is set correctly when setArrowValidityVector = true
2) Reuse container logic is now similar to row based read path
3) We now always set the nullability holder. Arrow validity vector is set only for purpose of supplying complete arrow vectors when requested to do so.

Cleanup and address code review comments.

Summary of changes:
1) Below new test cases added:
   - Test for code path when optional values are mostly null
   - Test for case when containers are not reused for every batch
   - Test for case to verify arrow's validity vector is set correctly when setArrowValidityVector = true
2) Reuse container logic is now similar to row based read path
3) We now always set the nullability holder. Arrow validity vector is set only for purpose of supplying complete arrow vectors when requested to do so.
